image_matrix.caption: On July 3, 1535, Paullu, the Inca Manco's brother and head of the Indian contingent to accompany the Almagro Expedition to Chile, is carried to Cuzco's central square to join Captain Almagro. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
The Battle of Andahuaylillas. In a driving rain, Captain Almagro, on the left, slashes and thrusts his way through attacking natives. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
Lake Titicaca natives prepare beds of earth in the shallow part of the Lake in preparation for the growing season. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
A chasqui runner with a message for the Inca in Cuzco. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
Paullu remonstrates with Lieutenant Alvarado about mistreatment of natives by the Spanish troops. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
The chief steward of the Inca's gold caravan prepares to meet with Captain Almagro and Paullu. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine

Conquistador Pedro de Mérida and Spanish horsemen struggle with their animals upon leaving Tucma (today's San Miguel de Tucuman) on the way to Fiambala. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.

Copayapu villagers celebrate the rare blooming of flowers in the desert by strewing them about the streets in joyful processions resembling this one. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.

In the mid-1470s, the new Inca, Tupac Inca Yupanqui, sent the first of three armies, each 10,000 strong, on their way to conquer the kingdom of Chile. Here, his general, Sinchiroca, is borne by litter as the army leaves the Andean fastnesses behind. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
Copayapu warriors arm themselves to resist the Inca invasion. They soon realized that to do so would be useless. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
Bartering by natives in and around Cuquimpu. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.

Lieutenant Alvarado, leading a search for gold outside Cuquimpu, attempts to intimidate a local chieftain into revealing where the natives have hidden the golden metal. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
Battle of Papudo. Pedro de Mérida, on the left, slashes through attacking warriors as his friend, Francisco de Valdéz, is unhorsed. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
Cuquimpu natives paddle to the Santiaguillo to unload its cargo. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
Years after the Indians built the huts on the summit of Llullaillaco, others dug burial places for sacrificial victims next to them. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
The Desert Cacique of Calama. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.

The Spanish charge before the walls of Fortress Arequipa. Lieutenant Centeño (with the white scarf over his mouth) is on his ride of death. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
Captain Valdivia (left) and Pedro de Mérida stare out over the location of the soon to be port of Valparaiso. Doña Inés de Suárez, the mistress of Valdivia, stands to the right.
Sancho de Hoz (left), after hearing his sentence of death, attempts to foil his executioners. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.

Araucanian Indians, under the leadership of Lautaro, defeated Pedro de Valdivia and the Spanish at the Battle of Tucapel in December 1553. Here, Araucanian warriors celebrate their victory. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
De Mérida and his wife, Pilca Huaca, on the porch of their plantation estate near Santiago. Courtesy Louis S. Glanzman and National Geographic Magazine.
